intro: Oxytropis zemuensis, commonly known as the Tibetan locoweed, is a perennial herb native to the high-altitude regions of Tibet and neighboring areas. It belongs to the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its slender, erect stems and small, clustered leaves. The plant produces yellow or pale purple flowers in late spring to early summer, which are typically arranged in racemes. Oxytropis zemuensis is adapted to harsh, arid environments and is often found in alpine meadows and rocky slopes. It is also known for its toxic properties, containing alkaloids that can be harmful to livestock.
